Yes, the German forces used several strategies to try and defend against the Allied assault, including:

1. Fortifications: The Germans built a series of fortifications and defensive structures, such as the Siegfried Line and the Atlantic Wall, to protect their territory. These fortifications made it difficult for the Allies to make progress in the early stages of the war.

2. Counterattacks: The Germans launched numerous counterattacks against the Allied forces to push them back and regain lost ground. These attacks were often heavily supported by artillery and air power.

3. Guerrilla tactics: As the Allies advanced deeper into German territory, the Germans resorted to guerrilla tactics such as sabotage, ambushes, and hit-and-run attacks to slow down the progress of the Allied forces.

4. Defensive positions: The Germans dug in and established defensive positions in key locations, such as on high ground or near natural obstacles like rivers and mountain passes. These positions were heavily fortified and defended by machine guns, artillery, and anti-tank weapons.

5. Mobile reserves: The Germans kept mobile reserves of troops and tanks in reserve to launch counterattacks against any Allied breakthroughs or to reinforce vulnerable areas of the front line. These reserves were often located behind the front line and only moved up when needed.
